Title: Calculate $\int_0^1\frac{\log^2(1+x)\log(x)\log(1-x)}{1-x}dx$
Content:
Prove that: $$ I=\int_0^1\frac{\log^2(1+x)\log(x)\log(1-x)}{1-x}dx=\frac{7}{2}\zeta(3){\log^22}-\frac{\pi^2}{6}{\log^32}-\frac{\pi^2}{2}\zeta(3)+{6}\zeta(5)-\frac{\pi^4}{48}\ln2  $$
 Using integration by parts: $$u=\log^2(1+x) \log x$$ thus $$du=\left[\frac{\log^2(1+x)}{x}+2\frac{\log x\log(1+x)}{1+x}\right]\,dx,  v=\log^2(1-x)$$
 We have:
  $$I= \left[-\frac{1}{2} \log^2(1-x)  \log x \log^2(1+x)\right]^1_0+\frac{1}{2} \int^1_0 \log^2(1-x) \log^2(1+x) \frac{dx}{x} + \int^1_0 \log x \log(1+x) \log^2(1-x) \frac{dx}{1+x}$$ How to calculate these last two integrals?

Problem_with_redundant_assumption:
Assumption:
Assumption 1: The integral is computed over the interval $[0, 1]$,
Assumption 2: The integrand is $\frac{\log^2(1+x)\log(x)\log(1-x)}{1-x}$.
Assumption 3: $$2\sum^\infty_{n=1}\sum^\infty_{k=1}\frac{1}{k^3(k+n)^2}=-\sum^\infty_{n=1}\sum^\infty_{k=1}\frac{1}{k^3n^2}+3\sum^\infty_{n=1}\sum^\infty_{k=1}\frac{1}{k^4}\left(\frac{1}{n}-\frac{1}{n+k}\right)$$
Problem:
Prove that $$I = \int_0^1 \frac{\log^2(1+x)\log(x)\log(1-x)}{1-x}dx = \frac{7}{2}\zeta(3){\log^22}-\frac{\pi^2}{6}{\log^32}-\frac{\pi^2}{2}\zeta(3)+{6}\zeta(5)-\frac{\pi^4}{48}\ln2.$$
